nodes.text: Expected utility theory can be given a dynamic interpretation: for a class of wealth dynamics the ergodicity transformation equals the utility function, so maximizing expected utility is equivalent to maximizing time-average growth of wealth
Context: Ergodicity economics distinguishes time averages from expectation values and posits agents maximize time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) instead of expectation values

Claim: For some wealth dynamics there exists an ergodicity transformation u(x) such that the time-average growth rate of wealth equals the expectation rate of change of u, making r = Delta u / Delta t an ergodic observable
Method: Model wealth as a stochastic process x(t) and introduce a monotonic transformation u(x); consider long-time limit of r = Delta u / Delta t and compare time average and ensemble average

Claim: Every invertible utility function u(x) corresponds to a unique wealth dynamics x(t) for which u(t) follows an additive process with stationary increments (Brownian motion with drift), and optimizing expected Delta u is growth-optimal

Assumption: Decision maker considers alternative stochastic processes and seeks actions that make wealth under the chosen process larger than alternatives with probability arbitrarily close to one for sufficiently large time

Result: Requiring time and ensemble averages of r to coincide leads to the condition that u(t) have stationary independent additive increments, implying u(t) is a Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW
Consequence: When u(t) is Brownian with drift the long-time limit of r exists and equals a_u, so the probabilistic decision criterion becomes optimization of the time-average growth rate

Method / Claim: Using Ito calculus, invertible twice-differentiable u(x) with u(t) Brownian yields an Ito SDE for x: dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW with coefficients determined by u and Brownian parameters

Claim: Conversely, given an Ito diffusion dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, a corresponding utility u(x) exists iff the coefficients satisfy relations that make a_u and b_u constant, yielding differential constraints relating a_x and b_x to u

Result: Examples recover known mappings: linear u(x)=x corresponds to additive Brownian wealth; logarithmic u(x)=ln x corresponds to geometric Brownian motion; square-root u(x)=sqrt(x) yields mixed additive-multiplicative dynamics

Example / Result: Integrating b_u = b_x(x) u'(x) gives u'(x) = b_u / b_x(x) and u(x) = integral of b_u / b_x(x) dx + constant; applied example with b_x = e^{-x} yields exponential utility u(x)=b_u e^{x}+C and corresponding dynamics where fluctuations shrink with x
Method / Result: The consistency condition yields ax(x) = (a_u / b_u) b_x(x) + (1/2) b_x(x) b_x'(x), so checking these relations determines existence of u without constructing it explicitly

Result: From u(t) normal distribution Pu(u,t) = Normal(a_u t, b_u^2 t) and change of variables gives closed-form wealth distribution Px(x,t)=Pu(u(x),t) du/dx, exemplified for u(x)=b_u e^{x}+C producing a skewed distribution with heavy lower tail

Conclusion: The correspondence gives a theoretical basis for choosing utility functions from exogenous wealth dynamics and predicts that risk preferences depend on dynamics rather than fixed psychological traits

Limitation / Note: The framework requires invertible, unbounded utility functions and continuous-path processes (Brownian in utility); dynamics that do not admit such u(x) cannot be given the same EUT-by-time interpretation
